member.name: T:Ipfs.Cid
member.summary: Identifies some content, e.g. a Content ID.

remarks.para: A Cid is a self-describing content-addressed identifier for distributed systems.
Initially, IPFS used a as the CID and this is still supported as 0. Version 1 adds a self describing structure to the multi-hash, see the spec.
remarks.note: The hashing algorithm must be "sha2-256" for a version 0 CID.

member.name: F:Ipfs.Cid.DefaultContentType
member.summary: The default .

member.name: M:Ipfs.Cid.EnsureMutable
member.summary: Throws if a property cannot be set.
member.exception: When a property cannot be set.
member.remarks: Once is invoked, the CID's properties cannot be set.

member.name: P:Ipfs.Cid.Version
member.summary: The version of the CID.
member.remarks:
When the is 0 and the following properties are not matched, then the version is upgraded to version 1 when any of the properties is set.
equals "dag-pb"
equals "base58btc"
algorithm name equals "sha2-256"
The default is "base32" when the is not zero.

member.name: P:Ipfs.Cid.Encoding
member.summary: The encoding of the CID.
member.value: base58btc, base32, base64, etc. Defaults to .
member.remarks: Sets to 1, when setting a value that is not equal to "base58btc".

member.name: P:Ipfs.Cid.ContentType
member.summary: The content type or format of the data being addressed.
member.value: dag-pb, dag-cbor, eth-block, etc. Defaults to "dag-pb".
member.remarks: Sets to 1, when setting a value that is not equal to "dag-pb".

member.name: P:Ipfs.Cid.Hash
member.summary: The cryptographic hash of the content being addressed.
member.value: The of the content being addressed.
member.remarks:
Sets to 1, when setting a hashing algorithm that is not equal to "sha2-256".
If the equals identity, then the is also the content. This is commonly referred to as 'CID inlining'.

member.name: M:Ipfs.Cid.ToString
member.summary: Returns the string representation of the CID in the general format.
member.returns: e.g. "QmXg9Pp2ytZ14xgmQjYEiHjVjMFXzCVVEcRTWJBmLgR39V"

member.summary: Returns a string representation of the CID according to the provided format specifier.
member.param: A single format specifier that indicates how to format the value of the CID. Can be "G" or "L".
member.returns: The CID in the specified .
member.exception: is not valid.

remarks.para: The "G" format specifier is the same as calling .

member.name: T:Ipfs.CoreApi.IBitswapApi
member.summary: Data trading module for IPFS. Its purpose is to request blocks from and send blocks to other peers in the network.
member.remarks:
Bitswap has two primary jobs
Attempt to acquire blocks from the network that have been requested by the client
Judiciously (though strategically) send blocks in its possession to other peers who want them

member.name: T:Ipfs.CoreApi.IDnsApi
member.summary: DNS mapping to IPFS.
member.remarks: Multihashes are hard to remember, but domain names are usually easy to remember. To create memorable aliases for multihashes, DNS TXT records can point to other DNS links, IPFS objects, IPNS keys, etc.

member.name: M:Ipfs.CoreApi.IDnsApi.ResolveAsync(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Resolve a domain name to an IPFS path.
member.param: An domain name, such as "ipfs.io".
Resolve until the result is not a DNS link. Defaults to false.
Is used to stop the task. When cancelled, the is raised.
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation. The task's value is the resolved IPFS path as a , such as /ipfs/QmYNQJoKGNHTpPxCBPh9KkDpaExgd2duMa3aF6ytMpHdao.
member.remarks:
A DNS TXT record with a "dnslink=..." entry is expected to exist. The value of the "dnslink" is an IPFS path to another IPFS object.
A DNS query is generated for both and _dnslink..
member.example: ResolveAsync("ipfs.io", recursive: false) produces "/ipns/website.ipfs.io". Whereas, ResolveAsync("ipfs.io", recursive: true) produces "/ipfs/QmXZz6vQTMiu6UyGxVgpLB6xJdHvvUbhdWagJQNnxXAjpn".

member.name: T:Ipfs.Duration
member.summary: Parsing and stringifying of a according to IPFS.
member.remarks:
From the go spec.
A duration string is a possibly signed sequence of decimal numbers, each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms", "-1.5h" or "2h45m". Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "µs"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".

member.summary: Converts the string representation of an IPFS duration into its equivalent.
member.param: A string that contains the duration to convert.
member.returns: A that is equivalent to .
member.exception: is not a valid IPFS duration.
member.remarks:
An empty string or "n/a" or "unknown" returns .
A duration string is a possibly signed sequence of decimal numbers, each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms", "-1.5h" or "2h45m". Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "µs"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".

member.name: T:Ipfs.MultiAddress
member.summary: A set of steps describing how to build up a connection.
member.remarks:
A multi address emphasizes explicitness, self-description, and portability. It allows applications to treat addresses as opaque tokens which avoids making assumptions about the address representation (e.g. length).
A multi address is represented as a series of protocol codes and values pairs. For example, an IPFS file at a sepcific address over ipv4 and tcp is "/ip4/10.1.10.10/tcp/29087/ipfs/QmVcSqVEsvm5RR9mBLjwpb2XjFVn5bPdPL69mL8PH45pPC".
A multi address is considered immutablle and value type equality is implemented.

member.name: T:Ipfs.Registry.HashingAlgorithm
member.summary: Metadata and implemetations of a IPFS hashing algorithms.
member.remarks:
IPFS assigns a unique and to a hashing algorithm. See hashtable.csv for the currently defined hashing algorithms.
These algorithms are implemented:
blake2b-160, blake2b-256 blake2b-384 and blake2b-512
blake2s-128, blake2s-160, blake2s-224 a nd blake2s-256
keccak-224, keccak-256, keccak-384 and keccak-512
md4 and md5
sha1
sha2-256, sha2-512 and dbl-sha2-256
sha3-224, sha3-256, sha3-384 and sha3-512
shake-128 and shake-256
The identity hash is also implemented; which just returns the input bytes. This is used to inline a small amount of data into a .
Use to add a new hashing algorithm.

member.name: T:Ipfs.Varint
member.summary: A codec for a variable integer.
member.remarks:
A VarInt is encoded in network byte order (Big Endian). Each byte (except the last) contains 7 bits of information with the most significant bit set to 1. The last byte has MSB set to 0.
Negative values are not allowed. When encountered a is thrown.
